This is Joyce Farrell.

Let's take a look at
Boolean expressions

and how they're used
in decisions.
Here's a selection structure.

With a selection structure,
you ask a question.

If the answer to the question
is yes, you take one course

of action, and if the answer
to the question is no,

you take a different
course of action.

The question in a
selection structure is a
Boolean expression.

Boolean expression is one
in which the result is one
of two values - true or false.

If you're talking to a
human, you can ask a question
like when is your birthday.
The human can answer August 3rd.

When you're talking
to a computer and say
when is your birthday,

the computer cannot
answer that question.

The computer internally
can only answer questions

that are Boolean expressions
that result in yes or no.

So, you can ask a computer
is your birthday June 24th,

and the computer can say no
or yes as the case may be.

If you want to find out when
the computer's birthday is,

it could take a lot
of questions.

You might say, "Is your
birthday January 1st?"
The computer says no.
"Is it January 2nd?"
No. "Is it January 3rd?"

No. Arg. This could
take a long time

to find the birthday, especially
if it's in August or September.

Fortunately, there are
six comparison operators

that you can use to
create Boolean expressions.

Not only can you see if one
thing is equal to another,

is your birthday August
3rd, but you can see

if one thing is greater
than another,

does your birthday
come after August 3rd,

or see if it's less
than something else.

Or you can compare two values,
and see if one is greater than

or equal to the other one, or
if one is less than or equal

to the other one, and finally
you can ask a question are two
things not equal to each other.

So to find out the computer's
birthday, perhaps using the less

than or equal to operator,
you might start in the middle

and say is your birthday
less than or equal to July 1st?

Does it come before
July 1st in the year?

And supposing the computer's
birthday is August 3rd,
the computer says no.
So then you might ask, OK, then.
It's not before July 1st.

Is it before or equal to October
1st, and the computer then,

assuming it's in
August, might say yes.

And then you might
say, OK, then.
We've narrowed it down.

Is your birthday less than
or equal to August 15th?

And assuming it's August 3rd,
the computer would say yes.
And so on.

By using the other
comparison operators,

you can ask questions
much more efficiently

than if you always had to
ask equal to questions.

Boolean expressions can
become even more complicated.
You can combine questions.

You might ask someone is your
birthday not December 19th,

or is your birthday
in April or May.

Or is your birthday September
2nd, and does that fall

on a weekend, and are
you free that night.

We'll talk more about
or and and operators

and how they work
in another video.
Thanks for watching.
